title.narrative: COVID-19 WFP - UNICEF Joint Programme on Social Protection in Uganda 2019-2024
COVID-19 WFP - UNICEF gemensamt program social trygghet i Uganda 2019-2024

description.narrative:
Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 Omprogrammerade medel för att lindra konsekvenserna av covid-19 WFP i samarbete med UNICEF har ansökt till Sida om 477 000 000 SEK (49 499 474 USD) i stöd för att genomföra programmet "Child-Sensitive Social Protection in Refugee-Hosting Districts of West Nile, Uganda" under perioden 2019-2024.
Programmet syftar till ökad motståndskraft och social trygghet, förbättrad hälsa och nutrition för utsatta barn och mödrar i West Nile i norra Uganda.
Den övergripande inriktningen på programmet är att stärka och komplettera existerande nationella program och system för social trygghet och hälsa med fokus på att göra dessa system mer effektiva och mer inriktade på att motverka barns utsatthet och främja bättre nutrition. Programmet förväntas göra pågående stöd mer hållbara och ta tillvara synergier genom att utnyttja resurser från befintliga nationella program, basservice och system för att nå starkare resultat för resiliens, hälsa och nutrition.
Programmets övergripande mål är stärkt ekonomisk inkludering av hushåll, förbättrad hälsa och nutrition för mödrar och barn. Det är inriktat på nexus mellan humanitärt stöd och långsiktigt utvecklingssamarbete genom att stärka införlivandet av flyktingar i existerande nationella system för hälsa och social trygghet.
Programmet syftar till att nå effekter på två nivåer; direkt för målgruppen, samt på systemnivå. Effekter på systemnivå förväntas uppnås genom att programmet bidrar till mer effektiva och transparenta system för social trygghet och hälsa med stärkt barn-perspektiv och ökad nutritionskänslighet.
Stödet till systemnivå länkas till pågående program för social trygghet (såsom SAGE - Social Assistance Grants for Empowerment, NUSAF3 - Northern Uganda Social Assistance Fund och DRDIP - Development Response to Displacement Impacts Project) och förväntas åtgärda brister i systemen för hälsovård och social trygghet.
Dialoginsatser riktade till målgruppen ska stärka efterfrågan på hälsovård och bidra till förändrat beteende som stärker resiliens, hälsa och nutrition.
De planerade effekterna för målgruppen är: - Ökad eller mer tillförlitlig inkomst genom kontantstöd - Förbättrad tillgång till marknader med lägre priser och högre variation på livsmedel - Mer varierad diet för hushållen - Förbättrad tillgång till kvalitativ hälsovård - Förbättrad efterfrågan på hälsovård
Programmet administreras av WFP genom ett standardavtal "Standard Administrative Agreement (SAA) for joint UN programmes" och implementeras av WFP och UNICEF i samarbete med lokala aktörer och ansvariga ministerier för social trygghet och hälsa. Det systemstärkande stödet bygger på pågående insatser av UNICEF och WFP för att stärka hälsosystemet, ge humanitärt stöd till flyktingar och stärka systemet för social trygghet. Det föreslagna stödet kompletterar pågående humanitärt stöd från WFP till flyktingar och bidrar till att utveckla mer hållbara lösningar i den långvariga humanitära situationen. Pågående stöd från UNICEF för att stärka hälsosystem och hälsotjänster kommer att införlivas i det föreslagna programmet som kommer vara mer integrerat och holistiskt.
En ny aspekt i programmet är komponenten för social trygghet med förmedling av kontantstöd till mottagare. Det förväntas bidra till effektiv fattigdomsminskning för sårbara hushåll och ge en förbättrad situation för både flyktingar och värdbefolkning vilket kan minska spänningar i dessa samhällen där risken för konflikt över otillräckliga resurser och samhällsservice har ökat efter det stora flyktingmottagandet. Programmet syftar också till påverka marknader för att öka tillgång till och variation av näringsrika varor till lägre priser.
Jämställdhetsperspektivet integreras tydligt i insatsen och en fördjupad analys kommer göras under det första året av kopplingen mellan jämställdhet, funktionshinder, hälsa och nutrition i de valda distrikten.
Programmet genomförs med en flexibel ansats där genomförandet utvecklas och anpassas i nära samarbete med nyckelaktörer i statliga strukturer på nationell och lokal nivå för att säkerställa hållbarhet. Den integrerade insatsen där WFP och UNICEF samarbetar förväntas också bidra till ökad effektivitet, kvalitet och långsiktig hållbarhet.
Stödet till systemen för social trygghet och hälsovård kompletteras av implementeringsforskning som både stödjer genomförandet av programmet och bidrar till kvalitativt, evidensbaserat, lärande. Detta förväntas bidra till att stödja den långsiktiga utvecklingen av systemen för social trygghet och hälsovård i Uganda.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 Reprogrammed funds to mitigate the impact of COVID-19 WFP in cooperation with UNICEF has applied to Sida for 477 000 000 SEK (49 499 474 USD) to support implementation of the programme "Child-Sensitive Social Protection in Refugee-Hosting Districts of West Nile, Uganda" during the period 2019-2024. The programme aims to achieve increased resilience and social protection, improved health and nutrition for vulnerable children and mothers in West Nile. It has a focus on the nexus between humanitarian support and long-term development cooperation through strengthening the inclusion of refugees in existing national systems for health and social protection. The overarching philosophy of the programme is to not create new programmes and systems, but to strengthen and complement existing, national social protection and health programmes and systems with a strong focus on making such systems more efficient and effective and more child- and nutrition-sensitive. This approach seeks not only to make program results sustainable, but also to help leverage the efforts and resources of these national programmes, services and systems to achieve enhanced results, in particular in terms of resilience, health and nutrition.The programme objectives are improved economic inclusion of households, improved maternal and child nutrition and improved maternal and child health. Programme outcomes are pursued at two levels; the level of direct beneficiaries of programme activities and the level of systems. The programme aims to affect the systems level through achieving more efficient, transparent, child- and nutrition-sensitive social protection systems as well as more efficient child- and nutrition-sensitive health systems. The systems-strengthening support will link to ongoing social protection programmes (such as SAGE, Social Assistance Grants for Empowerment, NUSAF3, Northern Uganda Socail Assistance Fund, DRDIP, Development Response to Displacement Impacts Project) and will cover essential gaps in current health care and social protection systems.Behavioural change communication directed to beneficiaries will support increased demand for services and changed behaviour that improves resilience, health and nutrition.The outcomes for targeted beneficiaries will be:- Increased or more secure income, through cash transfers- Improved access to markets, with lower prices and higher diversity - Improved dietary diversity- Improved access to quality health services- Improved health-seeking behaviourThe new aspect of the programme is the social protection component with direct cash transfers to beneficiaries. This component is expected to add to efficient poverty reduction for vulnerable households and to provide an improved situation for both refugees and the refugee hosting population which can decrease tension in these societies where the risk for conflicts over insufficient resources and services has increased after the refugee influx. The programme also aims to affect markets to achieve increased availability and diversity of essential goods at lower prices.The gender perspective is clearly integrated in the programme and an in-depth analysis will be undertaken during the first year of the linkages between gender, disability, health and nutrition in the selected districts. The programme will be implemented through a flexible approach, where implementation will be developed and adapted in close collaboration with key actors in existing government structures at national and local level to ensure sustainability. The integrated approach combining efforts of WFP and UNICEF is also expected to improve efficiency, quality and long-term sustainability.

The overall objective of the programme is to achieve improved community and household resilience among refugees and host populations in refugee-hosting districts of West Nile.
The overall objective is broken down into three specific programme objectives:
- Improved economic inclusion of households - Improved maternal and child nutrition - Improved maternal, neonatal and child health
These objectives are broken down in a number of outcomes on both beneficiary and system levels:
Outcome 1.1 - Increased or more secure incomes Outcome 1.2 - Improved access to markets Outcome 1.3 - Improved dietary variation of households Outcome 1.4 - Improved access to health services Outcome 1.5 - Improved health seeking behaviour Outcome 2.1 - More efficient, transparent, child- and nutrition-sensitive social protection systems. Outcome 2.2 - More efficient, transparent, child- and nutrition sensitive health services
The programme will deliver a number of results on output level in order to achieve the outcomes and overall objectives. - Support links with on-going Social Protection Programmes - Provide child sensitive household transfers - Support cash transfer mechanisms - Support beneficiary information and assistance management (BIAM) - Support retail markets - Support to feedback and complaints systems - Health system strengthening and support - Social Behaviour Change Communication for increased demand for health services
There is also a component on operational research for continuous learning and improvement of social and health services.
Update September 2020: The annual report for 2019 included a proposed revised results framework for the UNICEF-led component. The changes include a revised results nomenclature which in summary changes the semantics to an Impact, Outcome, Output structure. Secondly, there is a revision of some of the indicators to better align with the programme design, as well as with UNICEF's Country Programme Document and approved UNICEF Rolling WorkPlans (2019-2020). UNICEF concludes that "despite the adjustments to the results framework, the programme's implementation framework remains unchanged from what was originally envisioned and submitted by UNICEF in the approved Programme Document." The changes were approved by Sida in the feedback on the report sent on 29 June 2020 (archived).

title.narrative: Avtal - 11739 WFP-UNICEF Gemensamt program social trygghet i Uganda

description.narrative:
The summart below is based on the annual report for 2020 and the Embassy's continuous follow-up of the programme.
Summary of key results Component 1: Social Protection (WFP-led) COVID-19 emergency cash transfer
To address the COVID-19 pandemics socio-economic impacts on vulnerable individuals in the programme area, the Embassy approved a request for reallocation of USD 4,2m in June 2020, for a one-off nutrition-sensitive emergency cash transfer to pregnant and lactating women (PLW) and children under two years (U2), to help meet their essential food security and nutritional needs. The transfer targeted beneficiary households in the government programmes Development Response to Displacement Impacts (DRDIP) and Northern Uganda Social Action Fund Phase 3 (NUSAF3), together with participants in the WFP-supported Maternal and Child Health and Nutrition (MCHN) programme. The first round of the transfer was implemented between July to December 2020 and reached 62,261 beneficiaries across the six refugee hosting districts (RHD). 42 per cent of the recipients were PLW and 58 per cent were U2; while 59 per cent were refugees and 41 per cent were nationals. Planning figures overestimated the number of potential beneficiaries due to discrepancies with MCHN data, and with the unused funds WFP and OPM delivered a second emergency transfer in 2021 to the same target group in the MCHN programme, and to new PLW and U2 in DRDIP expansion areas in the six RHDs, plus Arua and Moyo districts. The total number reached was approximately 59,000 cash transfer recipients in July and August 2021.
The Embassy, WFP and UNICEF conducted a joint field mission to West Nile to observe the emergency COVID-19 transfer implemented by OPM and WFP, and various health system strengthening activities that UNICEF supports. Two distribution points were visited in Rhino Camp settlement where the mission could witness the implementation and interact with beneficiaries, local government and implementing staff.
Nutrition-sensitive cash transfer (NutriCash): WFP is leading the design and implementation of a nutrition- and child-sensitive cash transfer. To maximise linkages between the household transfer and the health system strengthening component, WFP agreed with UNICEF to leverage nutrition services and communication campaigns together with additional resources to support vulnerable households to afford a nutritious diet. The design of NutriCash began with a concept note that was revised in consultation with various national and district government stakeholders, donors and civil society. The note was approved by the steering committee in October 2020 after which an Impact Pathways workshop organized in December 2020 with participation from key stakeholders across government, donors and civil society. Following lengthy negotiations with the Office of the Prime Minister with simultaneous preparations and implementation of the second round of the emergency cash transfers, the design of NutriCash was finally agreed with and endorsed by DRDIP in September 2021. The Embassy participated in the official launch of NutriCash in Arua on 9th December 2021, under the theme "Towards zero hunger! Transformative nutrition outcomes through cash plus programming". The launch was successfully hosted by Arua District, with senior government participation through two state ministers from OPM and MGLSD as well as a recorded special address from the First Lady.
Component 2: Health package (UNICEF-led)
Improved access to quality health, HIV and nutrition services: UNICEF focuses on district health systems strengthening, while closely collaborating with WFP on the design of NutriCash linked to health and nutrition service delivery and nutrition behavioural change communication. In the first year of the programme UNICEFs interventions achieved results in the six RHDs and seven most marginalized districts of the West Nile. Trend analysis of outcome level results shows e.g. an increase in utilisation of childbirth, nutrition and HIV care services in health facilities in West Nile districts in 2020 compared to 2019. Detailed statistics are provided in the 2020 annual report.
Improved health seeking behaviour: In 2020, UNICEF supported the government to finalize and produce the key family care practices (KFCP) package, which represents a multi-sectoral communication approach developed and implemented jointly by health, education and gender ministries in order to harmonize messaging on health, nutrition, development, protection of children and reach communities through multiple platforms. The KFCP package articulates key messages across the life cycle, encourages positive care and care-seeking behaviours, and promotes community participation in the planning, delivery and monitoring of essential health, nutrition and other well-being services for children and women. KFCP messages are disseminated through existing platforms and structures, such as health facilities, schools, places of worship and community meetings. In addition to the technical support provided at the national level, UNICEF organized training of trainers, who in turn oriented over 9,833 village health teams (VHT) in the focus districts. Social and behaviour change communication activities made use of technology solutions, including FamilyConnect (FC) reaching over 2,500 new pregnant women with key messages. As a result, 166,450 pregnant women were visited at home. Alongside supply-side interventions, these activities have contributed to maintaining utilisation of essential services.
Better and more efficient health service systems: To strengthen evidence-based planning, ensure frequent monitoring of service delivery and utilization, and support meaningful community engagement, UNICEF and AVSI organized capacity building sessions for the targeted district local governments. A UNICEF-supported follow-up assessment of district health systems using the progression model approach showed that 7 out of 11 districts achieved basic capacity levels scoring 70 per cent or higher. Maracha, Obongi and Pakwach registered the strongest improvements in capacity while Nebbi regressed. Improvements in the level of client satisfaction with health services was modest, increasing by 6 percentage points only and reaching 33 per cent in 2020.
